body:
An interesting use-case and thanks for raising this issue.

Seems like the code should first call [FileSystem.getFileSystem(URI)](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/FileSystems.html#getFileSystem-java.net.URI-) in order to check whether a file system was already created for the passed URI. Not sure though, how the requested `CloseablePath` instance should be treated: ignore/discard it, register a duplicate, ... ?

> Since JUnit no longer supports performing test discovery once for multiple executions (which is ideal for my use case), I am forced to perform repeated test discovery each time I invoke the JUnit launcher.

Could you please elaborate? Are you running the same set of tests concurrently or repeatedly?

Thanks for the quick response. I am running the same set of tests concurrently (this is a hard requirement for my application). I believe if the tests are run in a single threaded environment this issue does not happen. 

Initially I explored using a single `TestPlan` so that I could perform test discovery once and avoid the cost of having to do test discovery multiple times for the same test suite. What I found when I attempted to do this was an exception saying that a `TestPlan` can only be executed once https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/main/junit-platform-launcher/src/main/java/org/junit/platform/launcher/core/InternalTestPlan.java#L43-L47 (I believe due to some state being shared between the `TestPlan` and engine). 

I did try modifying the JUnit source code to first call `Filesystem.getFileSystem(URI)` when the filesystem already exists. There was then a subsequent race condition on the first thread to call `.close()` found here https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/main/junit-platform-commons/src/main/java/org/junit/platform/commons/util/CloseablePath.java#L71-L74

> I am running the same set of tests concurrently (this is a hard requirement for my application).

What's the use case for that? Why would you run the same tests multiple times concurrently?

> What's the use case for that?

I am trying to run JUnit tests at a high load, without having to go through the effort of having to rewrite the tests. I also want to use the JUnit listeners that are provided for each test execution to get summary data on the number of tests which are passing / failing / started. 

> Why would you run the same tests multiple times concurrently?

Similar to my response above, I need concurrency to generate a sufficient level of load to run these tests at. Some of the tests that my tool runs involve a network call.  To generate a sufficient number of invocations per second multiple threads are necessary. 

To help you understand my use case consider the tool JMeter https://jmeter.apache.org/ which is designed for measuring system performance. What is different about my use case is that I want to leverage the JUnit launcher to do test discovery (JMeter implements their own version of discovering tests). 

Do you have any suggestions about how to reuse JUnit tests at a high load? For the most part JUnit works great for my use case, it is just this race condition during test discovery that is a problem. Thanks :)

@sormuras 

> Seems like the code should first call [FileSystem.getFileSystem(URI)](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/FileSystems.html#getFileSystem-java.net.URI-) in order to check whether a file system was already created for the passed URI. Not sure though, how the requested CloseablePath instance should be treated: ignore/discard it, register a duplicate, ... ?

Neither would work. The life-span of different file systems usages may overlap like so:

```
A: |-------------|
B:          |-------------|
```

Here closing the file system when A is done, would result in a failure of B. 

Or:

```
A: |-----------------------------|
B:          |-------------|
```

Here closing the file system when B is done, would result in a failure of A. 

If this is to be solved I don't believe this can be solved in any other way then by some form of reference counting in the `CloseablePath` implementation.

@oscargolding Thanks for elaborating! I wonder if you could avoid this situation by only calling `Launcher.discover` with classpath scanning once, inspecting the returned test plan, creating a new discovery request with class or unique id selectors, and using that one for all subsequent, concurrent calls to `Launcher.execute`. Would that work for you?

> My only question is about the safety of the approach? I understand doing test discovery like this is not exactly the standard approach outlined in the JUnit documentation.

Engines _should_ support that fully. Which engines are you using?
